newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean Kim orders steps to stabilise markets.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean Kim orders steps to stabilise markets.

text.p: South Korean president Kim Young-sam on Tuesday ordered his new cabinet to take steps to stabilise financial markets hit hard by the collapse of two leading steelmakers.

"The government should do its best to stabilise money and foreign exchange markets troubled by the application for court receivership by Sammi companies that followed the Hanbo incident," Kim told a cabinet meeting.
Hanbo Steel Co, South Korea's second largest steelmaker, collapsed in January under debts of $5.8 billion. Sammi Steel Co and its affiliates failed this month.
Kim said South Korea should press ahead with a banking reform and remove formalities and restrictions hampering the country's competitiveness.
Kim said the government must give top priority to revitalising the economy.
"The most pressing national task is reviving our economy," he said. A strengthened economy would help the government achieve other goals of national security and public wellbeing, he said.
"We have to gather our strength and wisdom to correct the distorted 'high cost, low efficiency' economic structure," he said.

South Korea has been suffering from a ballooning trade deficit due to a cyclical downturn in key export sectors, including semiconductors and ships, coupled with the Japanese yen's depreciation against the dollar.
The finance ministry forecast this year's current account deficit at about $18 billion, down from a record $23.72 billion shortfall in 1996.
The ministry also said it saw gross domestic product growth of 5.5 percent in 1997 against a 7.1 percent growth in 1996.
The new cabinet took office early this month.
